It was exciting to launch Nigeriaâ€™s Second National Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance (#AMR) and the National Genomic Surveillance Strategy, alongside my senior colleague, former Minister of Health, Professor Onyebuchi Chukwu, and my current colleagues, the Honorable Ministers of Agriculture and Environment, Honorable Dr. Amos Magaji, Chair of the House Committee on Tertiary Health, the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health, and the Director-General of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Dr. Jide Idris. Several of our partners were also present, including WHO, FAO, USAID, and many more. Their presence highlights our collective commitment to advancing Nigeriaâ€™s health security, a key pillar of President Bola Ahmed Tinubuâ€™s @officialABAT #RenewedHope Agenda for improving the health of all Nigerians.

These two critical documents are pivotal to the Nigeria Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative (#NHSRII), which focuses on building a resilient healthcare system, strengthening governance, and securing better health outcomes and health security. By addressing both current and future threats, these strategies position Nigeria as a leader in health security across Africa and globally.

Both the AMR National Action Plan and the National Genomic Surveillance Strategy are closely interconnected. The integration of genomic surveillance with our AMR efforts will strengthen our capacity to monitor bacterial pathogens and detect emerging threats before they spread widely. This synergy will enhance Nigeriaâ€™s role in the global fight against AMR while simultaneously improving our overall public health security.

AMR presents an urgent global challenge, contributing to 4.7 million deaths in 2021 alone. Nigeriaâ€™s Second National Action Plan on AMR was developed through extensive collaboration and adopts a One Health approach, integrating human, animal, and environmental health. Given that 67% of antimicrobial use occurs in the animal sector, this plan is crucial for curbing AMR and promoting responsible antimicrobial use across all sectors. Support from mechanisms like the #PandemicFund will be essential in financing these efforts and ensuring that Nigeria is equipped to combat AMR effectively.

The National Genomic Surveillance Strategy is equally vital. Genomic technologies will revolutionize the way we detect, monitor, and respond to infectious diseases. By integrating genomics into our AMR surveillance systems, we will enhance our ability to track pathogens, anticipate future health threats, and advance precision medicine and public health interventions.

Looking forward, Nigeria is positioning itself to host a high-level ministerial program on AMR within the next two years. We are in discussions to bring global leaders together in Nigeria to further advance our collective efforts in combating AMR. This will bolster efforts to enhance health security on the continent and beyond.

We appreciate the hard work of numerous experts who led deep stakeholder engagement to develop these strategic documents.

We also acknowledge the invaluable contributions of our development partners, including the World Health Organization @WHO, the Food and Agriculture Organization @FAO, @USAID, DRASA Health Trust @drasatrust, and the Clinton Health Access Initiative @CHAI_health. Thank you all.

The real work begins tomorrow, and with the commitment of all stakeholders, I am confident that we will make significant strides in building a healthier, safer Nigeriaâ€”a Nigeria that plays its part in African and global health security.

Today, I had the pleasure of meeting with His Excellency Salem Al Shamsi, UAE Ambassador to Nigeria @UAEEmbassyNGR, CEO of the Reaching the Last Mile Fund @RLMglobalhealth, Gates Foundation @gatesfoundation and Sightsavers @Sightsavers, focused on eliminating neglected tropical diseases (#NTDs) in Nigeria. These diseases, often affecting the most vulnerable and neglected folks in our society, are a significant concern as we continue to implement Mr Presidentâ€™s @officialABAT goal of achieving improving quality health outcomes for all Nigerians under the #RenewedHope Agenda.

NTDs such as onchocerciasis and lymphatic filariasis remain silent burdens on our communities, often overlooked because they affect those who have the least voice. Yet, it is these very diseases that we must address if we are to build a healthier, more prosperous Nigeria. The work being done under the Reaching the Last Mile initiative, supported by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan @mohamedbinzayed and the Gates Foundation @BillGates, is a testament to the power of collaboration in achieving this goal.

Our discussions today reaffirmed the need to continue scaling up efforts. With a new $500 million global expansion of the RLM program over the next six years, this effort is poised to bring treatments and life-changing interventions to millions of people all over the world. 

I emphasized the importance of partnerships. While external support is vital, Nigeria must take ownership of responsibility for its health outcomes. Our government will continue to work closely with our partners, through the #SWAp, to ensure that no effort is wasted and every resource is directed where it is needed most. This is not just about receiving assistance; itâ€™s about making sure we are building a system that can endure.

Letâ€™s continue this journey towards a healthier and more equitable Nigeria.

Today, it was truly inspiring to witness the launch of the groundbreaking partnership today between FIRST Exploration & Petroleum Development Company @FirstEandP and the Healthy Heart Foundation @HealthyHeartFdn. This collaboration marks a major milestone in addressing the growing burden of non-communicable diseases #NCDs in Nigeria, especially cardiovascular conditions. Beyond initiating an impactful effort, it paves the way for over 250 indigent Nigerians to gain access to life-saving cardiac surgeries and interventionsâ€”offering genuine hope to those most in need.

I extend my heartfelt congratulations to Dr. Yemi Johnson @yemij, Founder and CEO of First Cardiology Consultants, for his vision and commitment to addressing this critical healthcare challenge; to the Co-Founders of the Healthy Heart Foundation; and to Barrister Henry Odein Ajumogobia, SAN, OFR, @Oajumogobia, Chairman of FIRST E&P, for their strategic leadership. This partnership is a testament to how healthcare and corporate entities can unite to meet urgent health needs and unlock Nigeriaâ€™s vast human potential.

This initiative aligns perfectly with the Nigeria Health Sector Renewal Initiative (#NHSRII), particularly in the areas of improving quality health outcomes and unlocking the health sector value chain @PVAC_NG. It underscores the need for a strong healthcare infrastructure, expanding access to high-quality care, and enhancing financial protection for Nigerians through health insurance. It also reflects the core of the #RenewedHope agenda championed by His Excellency, Mr. President @officialABAT, whose commitment to alleviating the physical and financial burdens on Nigerians is a driving force behind this effort.

However, this partnership cannot stand alone. The rising tide of non-communicable diseases requires a collective response. I urge more private sector players, foundations, and philanthropic organizations to step up and collaborate with the government to ensure that high-quality healthcare becomes a right for every Nigerian, not a privilege. By combining our resources and expertise, we can magnify the impact of such initiatives, ensuring critical health services reach every corner of our nation.

Together, we can build a resilient and inclusive healthcare systemâ€”one that not only addresses the challenges of today but prepares for those of tomorrow. Let this partnership be a beacon, inspiring greater collaboration for the well-being of all Nigerians.

Today, at Redeemerâ€™s University @RedeemersUni, Ede, Osun State, I was glad to commission the new Institute of Genomics and Global Health, marking a significant evolution from ACEGIDâ€™s @acegid status as a center of excellence. This moment is not only a proud achievement for all those involved, but it also stands as a powerful symbol of what African scientific leadership can achieve on the global stage. Under the visionary leadership of Prof Christian Happi @christian_happi, the team at ACEGID has made extraordinary strides in genomic research, particularly in addressing some of the most pressing infectious disease challenges of our time.

The inauguration of the Institute reminds us that the work being done by the ACEGID team is a global public good, benefiting not only Nigeria and Africa but also contributing to global health security. The partnerships fostered between institutions and scientists from the Global North and South are a testament to our shared commitment to protecting and advancing human health. This collaboration has demonstrated what is possible when we work together to confront challenges that affect us all.

Under the visionary leadership of President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, @officialABAT health security remains a central pillar of our broader strategy to transform Nigeriaâ€™s health system, unlock the value chain, and improve population health outcomes. This is why supporting cutting-edge scientific research, like the work at this Institute, is essential. We need to create a health system environment with strong public health capabilities to withstand the potential and evolving threats posed by infectious diseases and the ongoing impacts of climate change.

The pace at which new health threats are emerging is accelerating, and with it, the need for robust scientific responses. The innovations in genomics we are witnessing at ACEGID provide a glimmer of hope, offering us the tools we need to be better prepared for what may come. The Federal Government of Nigeria @NigeriaGov is fully committed to supporting these efforts, knowing that science must lead the way in securing a healthier future for all.

Today, I had the pleasure of receiving, on behalf of Mr. President, His Excellency Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the leadership of the Nigerian Medical Association (@nationalnma), led by its President, Professor Bala Mohammed Audu. The NMA reaffirmed its commitment to supporting this administrationâ€™s efforts to transform healthcare and achieve quality Universal Health Coverage (#UHC) for all Nigerians.

The NMA praised Mr. Presidentâ€™s (@officialABAT) strategic initiatives, which are already making an impact in addressing critical challenges such as doubling training quotas for healthcare pre-service training, efficient waiver procedures for the recruitment of health professionals, workforce migration policy, improving health infrastructure and equipment to reduce medical tourism, expanding diagnostics and cancer care infrastructure, expanding primary care through the #SWAp with State Governments supporting health regulatory bodies, and expanding the vulnerable groups fund and insurance via NHIA (@NhisNg), etc.

I assured the NMA that Mr. President remains deeply committed to advancing healthcare with a respectful and dignified work environment for the Nigerian health workforce.

We understand the challenges that remain and are focused on improving the quality of healthcare services for Nigerians. We appreciate all health workers who are striving despite the obvious challenges we are facing as a country. However, the challenges are not insurmountable, as long as we keep the interest of Nigerians at heart and approach each other constructively.

We visited His Highness, the Emir of Misau, at his palace to express our sympathy for the victims of the devastating floods in Misau and Dambam LGAs. I also had the privilege of meeting with His Highness, the Emir of Katagum, the Emir of Jamaare, and the Sarkin Gamawa to address the situation in the affected areas, particularly in Gamawa.

On behalf of the Chigari Foundation @chigari_ngo, in partnership with well-wishers and the Nigerian Medical Association @nationalnma, we launched medical outreach services for thousands of citizens displaced by the floods, along with token contributions to support their immediate needs.

The floods we are witnessing in Nigeria, along with other impacts of climate change, are severely disrupting our food systems and ecology, leading to both acute and chronic malnutrition and the spread of waterborne diseases.

We hope that nations responsible for driving carbon emissions will recognize the need for justice and support our communities in adapting to these new global realities. The centuries-old resilience of our communities is being severely tested by the consequences of man-made global warming.

This past weekend, I visited the Ningi Emirate to personally offer my condolences on the passing of the former Emir, Alhaji Yunusa Danyaya, who served with distinction for 46 years. I also had the honor of congratulating the new Emir, His Highness Alhaji Haruna Yunusa Danyaya. May Allah grant eternal peace to the soul of our departed leader and bless the reign of his successor in the Ningi Emirate.

During my visit, I reflected on a key legacy of the late Emir, who had requested that the North East Vesico Vaginal Fistula (#VVF) Center be established in Ningi during President Jonathanâ€™s tenure, while I was Minister of State. Today, under President Tinubuâ€™s @officialABAT leadership, we have commenced free fistula surgeries for women suffering from this debilitating obstetric condition.

It was heartening to meet many women who recently received free and successful fistula surgeries and are on the path to rehabilitation and reintegration into society. Women had traveled from across Lagos @lagosstategov, Anambra @AnambraNewMedia, Borno @BornoGovt, Yobe @GovtYobeState, Niger @GovNigerNG, Bauchi @GovBauchi States, and even from neighboring Cameroon @PR_Paul_BIYA to receive this life-changing care.

I expressed my gratitude to Dr. Halima Muqaddas, the first female Medical Director of The National Obstetrics Fistula Centre Ningi, Bauchi State, and her dedicated team for their outstanding work, as well as to the National Health Insurance Authority @NhisNg for their vital financial partnership. Together, we aim to provide fistula repairs for over 10,000 vulnerable women over time.

Our commitment to the Sector-Wide Approach (#SWAp) in implementing the Nigeria Health Sector Renewal Initiative (#HSRII) centers on the well-being of our people, particularly women, children, and the most vulnerable members of society.

This afternoon, HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR @officialABAT, in-Council, approved a landmark policy set to transform healthcare human resource management in Nigeria.

The National Policy on Health Workforce Migration addresses the critical challenges facing Nigeriaâ€™s health human resources.

As the AU @_AfricanUnion Champion for Human Resources for Health and Community Health Delivery Partnership, Mr Presidentâ€™s commitment to a resilient and robust healthcare system is powerfully reflected in this forward-looking policy.

This policy is more than just a response to the ongoing exodus of healthcare professionals; itâ€™s a comprehensive strategy to manage, harness, and reverse health worker migration. It envisions a thriving workforce that is well-supported, adequately rewarded, and optimally utilized to meet the healthcare needs of all Nigerians.

Central to this vision is the Nigeria Human Health Resource Program, which sets a framework for regular reviews of working conditions, ensuring that health workers, especially in rural and underserved areas, receive the recognition and rewards they deserve. By fostering an environment conducive to professional growth and stability, the policy aims to retain top talent within Nigeria.

In an increasingly digital world, integrating advanced health technologies is essential. The policyâ€™s focus on digital health infrastructureâ€”including Electronic Medical Records (EMR), telehealth, and a comprehensive Health Workforce Registryâ€”marks a significant step towards a more efficient, data-driven health system. These innovations will streamline healthcare delivery and enhance the equitable distribution of health workers, ensuring access to quality care for all Nigerians.

Capacity building is at the heart of this policy. It recognizes the importance of continuous professional development, with strategic partnerships and opportunities for international training to equip our healthcare professionals with cutting-edge skills. This investment in human capital underscores our commitment to retaining and empowering our healthcare workforce.

The policy addresses the return and reintegration of Nigerian health professionals from the Diaspora. By establishing streamlined registration processes and providing attractive incentives, the policy not only encourages the return of our talented professionals but actively reintegrates them into our health system. This approach leverages the expertise of our diaspora to bridge gaps within the health sector.

Also, the policy champions reciprocal agreements with other nations to ensure that the exchange of health workers benefits Nigeria. These bilateral and multilateral agreements are designed to protect national interests while respecting the rights and aspirations of our healthcare professionals. We call on recipient countries to implement a 1:1 matchâ€”training one worker to replace every publicly trained Nigerian worker they receive.

Recognizing the importance of work-life balance, the policy includes provisions for routine health checks, mental well-being support, and reasonable working hours, especially for younger doctors. These measures aim to create a supportive work environment, reducing burnout and enhancing job satisfaction.

The governance of this policy will be overseen by the National Human Resources for Health Program (#NHRHP) within @Fmohnigeria, in collaboration with state governments. This ensures responsible implementation and alignment with broader sector-wide (#SWAp) health objectives.

With this decisive action, the National Policy on Health Workforce Migration is set to secure the future of Nigeriaâ€™s healthcare system. Under Mr. Presidentâ€™s leadership, this policy will further catalyze the transformation of our health sector, ensuring access to quality healthcare for all Nigerians.

As we embark on this journey, all stakeholders are invited to contribute to building a healthcare system that reflects our nationâ€™s potential and promise.

The agreement includes establishing a centralized facility for bioequivalence studies and advanced analytical laboratory services. This hub will ensure the quality of locally produced pharmaceuticals, leveraging USPâ€™s global expertise to boost local manufacturing capabilities.

Today, we inaugurated the National Emergency Medical Treatment Committee (#NEMTC) and signing the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on the Rural Emergency Service and Maternal Transport (#RESMAT) scheme. This event marks a pivotal step in advancing our emergency medical services, ensuring timely and efficient care for all Nigerians, especially the most vulnerable.

Under the leadership of President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT, we have prioritized the health of Nigerians, unveiling initiatives like the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative (#NHSRII) being implemented through the Sector-Wide Approach (#SWAp) program. These programs are designed to meet the needs of all Nigerians, particularly the poorest and most vulnerable, by enhancing governance, improving health systems, unlocking value through public and private sector collaboration, and bolstering health security.

The #NEMTC, with oversight from distinguished professionals, will coordinate efforts to reduce maternal mortality and improve emergency medical response. The committeeâ€™s multi-stakeholder approach includes federal, state, and local governments, private sector partners, and international organizations like the World Bank @WorldBank, ensuring a coherent strategy to elevate our health sector.

The #RESMAT initiative, in collaboration with #NEMSAS, aims to provide efficient emergency transport and medical services in rural areas. By addressing delays in accessing care, especially for pregnant women, we strive to lower maternal mortality rates and enhance overall health outcomes. This initiative leverages the Basic Health Care Provision Fund (#BHCPF) to finance emergency services, ensuring quality and timely care.

I would like to extend our appreciation to the key members who have made this possible: the Chairman of NEMTC, Dr Ismail Musa Jibrin; Professor Brisibe (Co-Chair, the Honorable Commissioner of Health of Bayelsa State); representatives from the National Blood Service Commission @MaltaNBS, National Health Insurance Agency @NhisNg, National Primary Health Care Development Agency @NphcdaNG, Nigeria Centre for Disease Control @NCDCgov, the Manager of NEMSAS within the Ministry @Fmohnigeria, the World Bank @WBG_Health, and all other esteemed members. The Compact is facilitating a coordinated approach to healthcare delivery, aligning efforts and resources to achieve common health goals. While local governments have been part of the Compact from the onset, recent developments have made their role even more robust and impactful.

text:
We are excited to announce the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Global Gases Group, led by Mr. Deepak Mehta, to establish gas plants for the production of liquefied medical oxygen in Nigeria. This collaboration aims to ensure a steady and reliable supply of high-quality medical oxygen across the country.

This partnership is a game changer for Nigeria and the subregion and directly aligns with the Nigeria Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative (#NHSRII) and the Presidentâ€™s @officialABAT @NigeriaGov Executive Order to unlock the healthcare value chain. The planned facilities, each capable of producing 100 tons per day, will be strategically located in 3 urban clusters located in North and South of Nigeria in the first phase. This will ensure that medical oxygen is accessible to a broader population, meeting both current and future demands.

The MoU outlines several key commitments from both parties. Global Gases Group (GGG) will complete feasibility studies and business case development, invest in technology, gas storage and distribution infrastructure, and provide necessary training and development for the project.

Utilizing cryogenic air separation technology, these plants will offer a sustainable, affordable, accessible, and scalable (SAAS) solution for medical-grade oxygen production. This technology provides higher purity levels (>99.5%) and reliability compared to traditional methods.

The project will also lay the groundwork for a more resilient and responsive healthcare system capable of withstanding future challenges such as pandemics. 

Importantly, it will contribute to local skill development and job creation.

Reflecting on the #Covid_19 pandemic, many Nigerians and @CEDEAO_ECOWAS citizens suffered due to severe oxygen shortages.

We extend our heartfelt thanks to the leadership of Global Gases and Dr. Abdul Mukhtar @Dr_AbduMukhtar of the Presidential Value Chain Initiative (@PVAC_NG) for their pivotal roles in making this partnership a reality.

text:
It was a great honor for me today to deliver a keynote address at the 5th Annual Legislative Summit on Health organized by the Senate Committee on Health in Abuja. The forum provided an invaluable platform to share the journey the Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare has embarked upon, in line with the Renewed Hope Agenda of President Tinubu @officialABAT, to transform Nigeriaâ€™s healthcare system through the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative (HSRII). Thank you, H.E. Sen. Dr Ipalibo Harry Banigo @HarryBanigo, for your leadership in convening the Summit.

At the very onset of our transformative journey for the nationâ€™s health sector, in collaboration with  Prof Margaret Kruk @mkruk and her team at Harvard T.H. Chan School @HarvardChanSPH, we harnessed insights from the Peopleâ€™s Voices Survey of 2,500 Nigerians to have an understanding of the healthcare experiences and expectations of our people.

We listened to concerns regarding healthcare access, affordability and quality. Many Nigerians struggled to access necessary quality medical services due to cost barriers, and there is a notable increase in non-communicable diseases, including hypertension, diabetes, and cancers, alongside persistent traditional health issues like maternal and child health, malaria, tuberculosis, and HIV.

In response to these challenges, the HSRII was developed and unveiled by Mr President in 2023. This initiative is structured around four critical pillars: governance, improving population health outcomes, unlocking the healthcare value chain, and health security. The raison dâ€™Ãªtre of the HSRII is to address systemic issues, optimize resource utilization, and ensure that all Nigerians have access to quality healthcare.

Significant successes have already been achieved under the Initiative. We have made substantial progress in improving governance through the signing of a Compact with all 36 state governors and the FCT; and 17 development partners to work collectively as a National Health System. The Compact has facilitated better coordination and alignment of efforts across all levels of Government, ensuring that resources are utilized efficiently and fragmentation kept in check.

On improving population health outcomes, we are on track to expand functional primary healthcare centers. Already, we have conducted two rounds of disbursements through the BHCPF, ensuring resources reach the front lines. Additionally, we are retraining 120,000 frontline health workers to enhance their skills and service delivery capabilities, with 7,000 workers already retrained in the 36 States. 

Unlocking the healthcare value chain is essential to reducing our dependency on imports. Currently, Nigeria imports 70% of the pharmaceutical generics and 99% of our medical devices. To address this, few weeks ago, Mr President signed an Executive Order to reduce tariffs on imports of raw materials and manufacturing equipment, encouraging local production and making our healthcare system more self-reliant.

Health security is a matter of national, economic, and global security. The COVID-19 pandemic and previous outbreaks like Ebola have underscored the importance of robust health security measures. Weâ€™re strengthening @NCDCgov, improving surveillance systems, and maintaining strategic stockpiles to ensure rapid response to health emergencies. Our swift and effective response to recent public health emergencies, such as meningitis and cholera outbreaks, demonstrates our commitment to protecting public health.

I want to extend my deep gratitude, once again, to the Chairman of @NGRSenate Committee on Health, Sen. Dr. Banigo, and other distinguished members of the Senate and the leadership of the House of Reps and their Committees, for their unwavering support and collaboration from the outset

As we move forward, I call for continued dedication to supporting the Presidentâ€™s Renewed Hope Agenda. Together, we can achieve improved health outcomes for all Nigerians.

It was a momentous occasion today for Nigeriaâ€™s health sector renewal as we commissioned several projects and ground breaking at the Nnamdi Azikiwe University Teaching Hospitalâ€™s Permanent Site. The projects included the Dr. Cletus Ibeto General Outpatient Department (GOPD) Complex, Sir Emeka Offor Medical Ward Complex, and the Sen. Dr. Ifeanyi Uba Medical Outpatient Clinic. Dr. Ifeanyi Ubah @Dr_IfeanyiUbah has played a crucial role in mobilizing the Anambra Progressives for funding the Medical Outpatient Clinic. Under the leadership of HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR @officialABAT, the Federal Government, through the Renewed Hope Agenda, is committed to delivering improved quality health outcomes for all Nigerians. The construction of access roads by the state government and the substantial investments by industry leaders exemplify the whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach necessary to achieve these goals.

text:
This morning, we had the pleasure of holding the inaugural Quarterly Performance Dialogue between the Federal Government, 36 State Governments, and all key stakeholders in the health sector. This  marks a bold and hopeful step towards transforming our health system through the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative and the Sector-Wide Approach, emphasizing the cooperative federalism mandated by the National Health Act of 2014.

Our goal is to foster shared responsibility and collaboration among all health providers across various levels of government, the private sector, and our invaluable development partners. This dialogue is affirms our unwavering commitment to improving population health outcomes for all Nigerians.

We are grateful for the steadfast support of our development partners, who ensure that resources are directed towards priority areas that will significantly enhance health outcomes for our citizens. This is not just about cooperation; it is about accountability and collective progress. We have agreed to hold each other accountable, learn together, and work together through regular performance dialogues and evaluations.

At the Federal Ministry of Health and Social Welfare @Fmohnigeria, we have committed to achieving several key indicators: improving Penta 3 coverage, increasing the proportion of fully immunized children, reducing the number of zero-dose children, enhancing the proportion of deliveries attended by skilled birth attendants, improving antenatal care coverage, and increasing access to health insurance and primary healthcare services. We are also committed to tracking the utilization rates of various services and the satisfaction of our population. We encourage states to track their progress against these indicators.

I extend my heartfelt gratitude to everyone participating in this dialogue and all who have rallied around this initiative. Special thanks to the SWAp Coordination Office, the Minister of State @DrTunjiAlausa, the Permanent Secretary, and other colleagues at the Ministry. I also commend Dr. Banji Filani @okeanaye for his remarkable leadership of the Hon Commissionersâ€™ Forum and all the Commissioners who have constructively co-created this mechanism. I am hopeful and confident that the 774 local governments will also join this effort to collectively improve the health of Nigerians, in line with the Presidentâ€™s @officialABAT Renewed Hope Agenda and the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative. Together, we can achieve a healthier, stronger Nigeria.

text:
This evening, at the Launch of the Private Sector Strategy to End Tuberculosis in Nigeria held in Lagos by the @StopTBNigeria, the message was clear: we know the statistics, we are leading in case identification, and the Government and its development partners are doing their part. Now, itâ€™s time for the private sector to join the fight against tuberculosis in Nigeria.

Tuberculosis remains a formidable challenge in our country, striking the poorest and most vulnerable, those who are often socially excluded. Despite our progress, we still face significant hurdles. The resources needed to sustain and expand our efforts are vast, and the burden on our health system is immense. This isnâ€™t just a health issue; itâ€™s a social and economic challenge that affects directly or indirectly every one of us.

In inviting the private sector into the fight against tuberculosis, we seek active partners who can amplify our efforts. We have the tools and knowledge to combat TB effectively, but we need your support. Imagine the impact of a strategic partnership where the Nigerian private sector leaders raise $25 million USD for tuberculosis initiatives, and the government and development partners match it. Together, we can ensure that our resources are used efficiently, effectively, and transparently, with a plan to monitor our progress over time.

The First Lady of Nigeria, Senator Oluremi Tinubu @SenRemiTinubu, and the First Lady of Lagos State, Dr. Ibijoke Sanwo-Olu @JokeSanwoolu, along with other First Ladies, have championed the fight against tuberculosis. Their leadership and advocacy have brought much-needed attention to this critical issue, inspiring action across all sectors of society. In a transformative move to revitalize the Nigerian health sector, His Excellency President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR @officialABAT, has signed an Executive Order aiming to increase local production of healthcare products (pharmaceuticals, diagnostics, devices such as needles and syringes, biologicals, medical textile, etc.). The Minister of Justice and Attorney General of the Federation @FedMinOfJustice, Prince Lateef Olasunkanmi Fagbemi SAN, @LOFagbemi, is to now take the next steps towards codifying the new Order. 

The Order is pivotal to the success of the Initiative for Unlocking the Health Care Value Chain (@PVAC_NG), which was approved in October 2023 by the President. 

The Order introduces zero tariffs, excise duties and VAT on specified machinery, equipment and raw materials, aiming to reduce production costs and enhance our local manufacturersâ€™ competitiveness. Specified items  include Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (#APIs), excipients, other essential raw materials required for manufacturing of crucial health products like drugs, syringes and needles, Long-lasting Insecticidal Nets (#LLINs) and Rapid Diagnostic Kits, among others. 

The Order also provides for establishing market shaping mechanisms such as framework contracts and volume guarantees, to encourage local manufacturers.

The Order mandates collaboration between the Ministers of Health @Fmohnigeria, Finance @FinMinNigeria, and Industry, Trade and Investment @TradeInvestNG to develop a Harmonized Implementation Framework, expediting regulatory approvals and reducing bottlenecks. Agencies including the Nigeria Customs Service @NgCustoms, @NafdacAgency, @SONNigeria, and @FIRSNigeria will ensure swift implementation, with special waivers and exemptions effective for two years.

The implication of this order is pivot towards market-based incentives to encourage medical industrialization, reducing costs of medical products through import substitution over time, creating and retaining economic value and enabling job creation in the healthcare value chain.

We thank Mr President for his courage and commitment to ensure Nigeria is put back on the path to prosperity. We also thank all who contributed to the ideas that culminated in the consensus that resulted in this key milestone.

Today, I was proud to inaugurate the â€œNHIA Fistula Free Program Flag-off and Inaugural Meeting,â€ marking a pivotal step in our commitment to tackling the severe healthcare challenge posed by obstetric fistula in Nigeria. Obstetric fistula affects approximately 100,000 women nationwide and results from prolonged and obstructed labor without timely medical intervention leading to unpleasant outcomes. The condition causes chronic incontinence and severe social and economic consequences, particularly for young, malnourished women from poor households. Each year, about 13,000 new cases arise, and without intervention, it could take up to 83 years to address the backlog of unrepaired cases.

Globally, obstetric fistula affects roughly 2 million women, with about 1 million cases in developing countries. This highlights the urgent need for comprehensive healthcare solutions, and Nigeriaâ€™s significant share of this burden underscores the critical importance of targeted interventions and robust healthcare policies.

In line with President Bola Ahmed Tinubu GCFR @officialABAT Administrationâ€™s prioritization of reproductive and maternal health, we are committed to ensuring no one is left behind. This commitment aligns with our broader goal of building an inclusive health system that reduces maternal morbidity and mortality and addresses the needs of the most vulnerable populations. The Fistula Free Program is a testament to this commitment, aiming to enhance financial access to care for women suffering from obstetric fistula.

The initial phase targets National Obstetric Fistula Centers in Katsina, Bauchi, Ebonyi, and Edo States, with plans to expand to other hospitals. It covers conservative and surgical treatments, transportation, education, counseling, mental health support, and family planning. A key component is enrolling these women in social health insurance programs to ensure the sustainability of care.

The Program is closely tied to the National Health Sector Reform Initiative #NHSRII and other key government initiatives aimed at making treatment affordable and accessible. Importantly, the programâ€™s focus on reducing physical and financial pain and saving lives for affected families aligns with the overarching goals of the NHSRII @Fmohnigeria. By prioritizing financial access to care and integrating services into the social health insurance system, the program aims to create a sustainable and inclusive healthcare solution.

The MoU we signed is critical to formalize  the collaborative effort between the NHIA, National Obstetric Fistula Centers, and selected HMOs to ensure a coordinated and effective approach to addressing obstetric fistula across Nigeria. It outlines the roles and responsibilities of each party and sets a framework for the committeeâ€™s tasks. 

The Committee will be action-oriented and results-driven in providing strategic guidance and direction, reviewing progress, making recommendations for improvement, advocating for prevention, and evaluating impact. These roles are crucial in ensuring that the program achieves its objectives and delivers tangible results for the affected women.

I would like to extend my gratitude to Dr, Kelechi Ohiri, the DG, @NhisNg and all the individuals and agencies involved in this process as well as the membership of the steering committee. Their dedication and collaborative efforts are crucial in driving this initiative forward, ensuring it is action-oriented and results-driven.

This Fistula Free Program, backed by the unwavering commitment of President Tinubu to reproductive and maternal health, represents a transformative step towards addressing obstetric fistula in Nigeria. As we move forward, the collaborative efforts of all stakeholders will be essential in significantly reducing the burden of this condition, improving health outcomes, and ultimately saving lives. The work we undertake today sets the foundation for a healthier and more equitable future for all Nigerians.

text:
Nigeria is unfortunately grappling with a significant malnutrition crisis, ranking among the countries with the highest burden of malnutrition globally. This crisis is concentrated mostly in the northwest and northeast, although no region is completely spared. 

The underlying reasons for this situation are multifaceted, including the nature of governance over several years, population dynamics with high dependency in the context of mass poverty in parts of the north, coupled with insecurity in certain areasâ€”although it is improvingâ€”the impact of climate change on agricultural productivity and food systems, feeding practices, and the societal economic disempowerment of girls and women.

According to recent UNICEF reports, approximately 2 million children suffer from severe acute malnutrition (#SAM), with 40% of these cases concentrated in six states. More than 6 million children are moderately malnourished, and many women (pregnant and lactating) suffer from micronutrient deficiencies.

In line with the Renewed Hope Agenda of Mr. President @officialABAT, we are now facing this crisis head-on. Addressing malnutrition is not only a moral imperative but also essential for improving health and ensuring the nationâ€™s sustainable development.

Our inter-ministerial and multi-partner meeting today was convened to assess ongoing efforts to tackle this crisis effectively. We appreciate the contributions of @UNICEF, @MSF, the @WorldBank, @WFP,  @RESCUEorg, BMGF @gatesfoundation, @fhi360, and several others who joined my colleagues from the government. We are encouraged by the potential to immediately unlock $30 million from the World Bankâ€™s #ANRIN project, as well as a potential 1:1 match from the Child Nutrition Fund.

We have established a ministerial task force to quickly develop a realistic yet ambitious action plan, focusing on immediate resource mobilization and practical actions to deliver solutions to those who need them most. This plan takes into account the substantial burden on girls and women alongside children.

Enhanced coordination is crucial, along with a strong bias for action. We will monitor progress and ensure accountability in deploying urgent interventions, including the distribution of micronutrient powders, therapeutic foods, and other nutritional supplements.

We will harness local production of therapeutic foods and other community-based interventions, strengthening and extending beyond the 1,192 treatment sites already in operation, mostly in primary healthcare centers.

We call on State Governments @NIGERIAGOVNORS, to also be on heightened alert, complement the efforts of various agencies in their respective states, and provide additional resources to manage this difficult phase. There is light at the end of the tunnel, and Nigeria will get through it with the steady, courageous leadership of HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR.

Hypertension remains a significant public health issue in Nigeria. It is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality due to its association with stroke, kidney / heart failure, and other non-communicable diseases (NCDs).

Today, we received a courtesy call from the Nigerian Hypertension Society and exchanged ideas on how to actively promote awareness for the prevention and control of hypertension through various media and educational programs.

Already, the Government of President Tinubu @officialABAT has integrated hypertension management into the national health agenda and other innovative programs like the National Hypertension Control Initiative.

Deliberate collaboration between Government and non-governmental bodies, including the private sector and the media, is critical to creating awareness and managing the scourge of hypertension. 

Hypertension is preventable and treatable; and we urge Nigerians to imbibe preventative measures including lifestyle changes like increased physical activity and traditional diet low in salt, sugar, and saturated fats. Also we should routinely monitor our blood pressures and blood sugar levels, among other wellness checks.

I thank the Society for their visit and the kind offer to check my blood pressure. It is a lifesaving habit which I would urge every susceptible individual to imbibe.

Hypertension is a silent killer and thrives on complacency. It is important that our men and women know their numbers.

As we celebrate the National Safe Motherhood Day, we would like to honor the lives of mothers in our nation by intensifying our efforts to prevent maternal deaths. This yearâ€™s Safe Motherhood Day calls us to action, reaffirming our dedication to end the loss of life due to maternal causes.

This yearâ€™s National Safe Motherhood Day is more than a celebrationâ€”itâ€™s a call to action. We remember the almost  57,000 women who lost their lives to maternal causes in the last year and reaffirm our commitment to reducing these numbers to through improved primary care and community engagement.

The Administration of HE President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT is committed to putting the Nigerian people at the center of all initiatives, ensuring that every policy and investment improves the well-being of our citizens. Central to this agenda is enhancing healthcare access and outcomes, particularly for mothers and newborns.

Last December, we launched the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative as a collaborative sector-wide effort with all 36 state governors, the FCT Minister, development partners, and the CSOs, aimed at revamping delivery of basic health services. The Compact we signed to implement the NHSRII focuses on creating a cohesive, effective approach to healthcare, especially maternal newborn and child health.

The recent approval of 25 billion naira under the BHCPF, to be implemented through the NPHCDA and NHIA gateways, aims to enhance more than 8,000 BHCPF facilities, with ambitions to expand them to over 17,000 in the next three years. This Fund is the cornerstone of our strategy to ensure universal access to primary healthcare.

With the goal of â€œInvesting in Maternal Health for a Sustainable Future,â€ under the slogan â€œMother Lives, Child Thrives,â€ we call on all stakeholders to collaborate with us in achieving our fervent mission to ensure that no woman dies from pregnancy and childbirth-related conditions. We are deploying resources, domestically and through our partners, to ensure that every newborn is protected and supported to thrive into healthy childhood.

Our commitment to strengthening primary healthcare remains unwavering. We have already started the retraining 120,000 frontline health workers and improving emergency obstetric services. we are working to ensure that every citizen receives quality care over time.

Also, as part of 2024 Safe Motherhood Day, Iâ€™m proud to launch the Guidelines for the Management of Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) at the community and health facility to accelerate the reduction of maternal and newborn morbidity and mortality. We will also support the local production of calibrated drapes and magnesium sulphate to ensure each pregnant woman has access to one calibrated drape.

Weâ€™d not achieve these milestones without the steadfast support of our development partners. So, Iâ€™d like to commend the efforts of the Safe Motherhood Sub-TWG and its partners, including the @WHO, @UNFPA, @UNICEF, Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation @gatesfoundation, @PPFNigeria, @USAIDGH, Pathfinder International @pathfindershq, MCG/@Jhpiego , IPAS @IpasOrg, TA-connect @TAConnect_NG, Clinton Health Access Initiative @CHAI_health, @SCIDaR_ , @SFHNigeria, @PlanGlobal, @WRAglobal, RMCH Rotary International @Rotary, and Marie Stopes International Organization Nigeria, @msichoicesng, among others, for their support.

text:
Effective governance of our health system architecture is critical to delivering improved quality health outcomes for all Nigerians as envisioned in the Nigeriaâ€™s Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative #NHSRIP. 

To succeed in this effort, we are fostering better coordination and partnerships across Federal and State departments and other agencies, anchored by @NafdacAgency, to increase transparency, effectiveness, and accountability of our regulatory processes. 

My hybrid meeting today with the DG NAFDAC @DGatNAFDAC and members of the of Federal Task Force on Foods and Drugs, consisting of State Commissioners of Health, Pharmacy Council of Nigeria, @PCN_Registry, and other agencies was to listen to their stories, successes, and challenges as well as recommendations on policy gaps that need to be filled to strengthen regulation.

It is good to see the seriousness with which NAFDAC, Pharmaceutical Council of Nigeria, State Commissioners, State Directors of Pharmaceutical Services, and other collaborating entities tackle the issue of fake and adulterated food and drugs, including substandard cosmetics and allied products in our markets. This is as it should be considering the exploding consequences of incidence of non-communicable diseases from these products.

Indeed, there may be connections between environmental exposure to chemicals, adulterated substances, and the distribution of unregulated foods and drugs, with the increase in diseases such as cancers, hypertension, diabetes, and kidney disease. 

And on the side of unlocking health care value chain, this could negatively impact our efforts, because if we don't have a well regulated system, we wonâ€™t be able to attract or retain veritable  investors or manufacturers as the counterfeit flow will undermine them. 

Going forward, we are ramping up collaborative efforts between the federal government and states, recognizing the decentralized  system we operate as a country. This is in addition to strengthening NAFDAC, federal and state task forces to address environmental and food safety issues.

Leveraging the Sector-Wide Approach, we will seek collaborations and support from international organizations such as the Global Fund, @GlobalFund, to enhance regulatory capacity.

On our part, through the strong commitment of Mr President @officialABAT, we will continue to prioritize effective governance of the health sector and, within available resources, try to secure adequate funding, including budget allocation for effective regulation nationwide.

text:
Nigeriaâ€™s healthcare sector is experiencing a transformation under President Tinubuâ€™s @officialABAT, leadership, with the approval of a Sector-Wide Approach (#SWAp) and the Health Sector Renewal Program (NHSRIP).

Key reforms are underway for the Basic Healthcare Provision Fund (#BHCPF), including guideline reviews and governance structure enhancements.

Our aim is to improve primary healthcare accessibility for vulnerable groups and reduce the need for patients to travel for care.

In a productive week during the holy month of Ramadan and Easter, we held the Ministerial Oversight Committee (#MOC) meeting on March 28 to discuss advancing Nigeriaâ€™s primary healthcare delivery through SWAp.

An assessment of the BHCPF highlighted the need for programmatic, operational, and fiduciary reforms.

All 36 states and the FCT have committed to addressing these issues through a remediation plan and a compact signed with the Federal Government.

Our objective is to enhance the health of Nigerians through efficient, effective, and quality primary healthcare.

At the MOC, we approved the release of 25 billion Naira to the National Primary Health Care Development Agency @NphcdaNG, and the National Health Insurance Authority, @NhisNg, from the BHCPF.

As an interim measure, while developing BHCPF 2.0, we approved half of the available funds to the States via the Gateways.

The redesigned BHCPF aims to align resources towards improving health outcomes, with a focus on maternal and child health. We anticipate significant additional investments to be channeled to the primary healthcare system once the redesign is completed by July 1, 2024.

The revised guidelines will prioritize vulnerable groups, aiming to reduce maternal mortality rates and out-of-pocket payments. They will also standardize quality of care measures across primary healthcare facilities.

Specifically, on the NPHCDA gateway, among others, the guidelines revision will include increasing direct facility financing in a tiered way to address health inequities, provide additional resources for supervision by States, support for frontline health workers, and drugs/commodities at the #PHC levels (more than 8,000 PHCs across the country), and strengthen financial management and accountability.

We are counting on citizens and civil society organizations and the media to keep a close watch on the resources once they start to flow to each BHCPF-supported PHC facility, to ensure they are used for intended purposes only.

We are providing a dedicated email address (bhcpfalert@health.gov.ng) and a dedicated phone line published on the website of the Federal Ministry of Health and other public portals, so that any citizen or civil society organization can report information on the potential misuse of BHCPF funds by anyone in the chain, from Federal, State, LGA, and facilities.

Our Ministerial oversight team will monitor and investigate credible reports, ensuring proper use of resources for primary care services.

We also urge relevant institutions such as the EFCC, @officialEFCC, ICPC, @icpcnigeria, and DSS @OfficialDSSNG, to keep a close eye and alert us in a preventative way if they receive credible information on any potential misuse of public funds.

Maintaining the integrity of the fiduciary system for PHC financing is a collective responsibility. Transparency is crucial, and all stakeholders must work together to combat corruption in our primary healthcare system.

As Nigeria embarks on this healthcare transformation, collaboration is essential.

On winding down the Holy Month of Ramadan and in this Lenten period, we join all in prayers for Nigeria to emerge from its current position and rise again, as envisioned in Mr. Presidentâ€™s Renewed Hope Agenda.

We also invite all Nigerians and friends of Nigeria to join us in praying for President Tinubuâ€™s strength, protection, and wisdom on his 72nd birthday.

text:
On behalf of the Global and Nigeriaâ€™s Stop TB Partnership, I extend heartfelt congratulations to Her Excellency, Senator Oluremi Tinubu, CON, @SenRemiTinubu, the First Lady of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, on her investiture as the Global and National Stop TB Champion, @StopTB.

This momentous appointment marks a significant milestone in Nigeriaâ€™s ongoing battle against tuberculosisâ€”a disease that disproportionately affects the most vulnerable in our society, including the socially excluded, the impoverished, and those suffering from malnutrition, HIV, and other comorbidities.

We are deeply grateful for Her Excellencyâ€™s willingness to lead this critical campaign. Her dedication to public health is evident in her immediate and affirmative response to championing this cause, aligning with her Renewed Hope Agenda Initiative and President Bola Ahmed Tinubuâ€™s @officialABAT, vision of empowering our nation.

We recognize the essential roles of religious and traditional leaders, civil society, and the private sector in combating tuberculosis. This whole-of-society approach echoes the sector-wide strategy introduced by President Tinubu in December 2023, aimed at fostering coordinated efforts across all sectors to improve outcomes for our population.

In line with the National Health Sector Renewal Investment Program, #NHSRIP, we are intensifying investments in primary healthcare, a key component in expanding the scope of services, including tuberculosis diagnosis and treatment. We are poised to announce significant investments in Primary Health Care Centers @NphcdaNG under the Basic Health Care Provision Fund #BHCPF program, incorporating tuberculosis services as an integral part of healthcare accessible to Nigerians. We are also enhancing our use of digital X-ray with artificial intelligence for TB screening, with the aim to add 350 digital X-ray machines before the end of June 2024, supported by our funding partners. Furthermore, we have instituted a robust specimen referral network utilizing a hub-and-spoke model, responsible for the transport of over 2.4 million samples in 2023 for TB tests.

Inspired by the visionary leadership of President Tinubu, we are committed to ensuring that Nigeriaâ€™s efforts in ending tuberculosis not only benefit our nation but also contribute positively to the global community. As a member of the Board of the Global Stop TB Partnership, and in my newly elected role in the Global Fund Board representing West and Central Africa from May 2024, I pledge to bridge the Presidentâ€™s domestic initiatives with the complementary support of our external and bilateral partners.

The collaboration of our State Governors, @NGFSecretariat, will be essential to amplify their investments in healthcare, particularly in the fight against TB. With the support of the First Lady, we are confident that States will be more equipped to allocate resources towards this critical health issue. I also extend gratitude to my colleague Dr. Tunji Alausa @DrTunjiAlausa, Minister of State for Health, and all public health colleagues for their relentless dedication, which has been instrumental in Nigeriaâ€™s achievements thus far.

We are grateful for the smart collaborations and contributions of our funding and technical partners, including the @GlobalFund and the @CDCgov, United States, the Stop TB Secretariat @LucicaDitiu, as well as the Nigeria Stop TB program. The expected outcomes of our Health Sector Renewal Investment Program were carefully benchmarked on disability-adjusted life years (DALY) indicators, considering the rising percentage of vulnerable and physically challenged groups among Nigeriaâ€™s population.

The program aligns with Nigeriaâ€™s ratification and commitment to implementing the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD), which guarantees the rights and fundamental freedoms of all persons with disabilities to respect and dignity in accessing quality healthcare. The Convention underpins a key pillar of Mr. Presidentâ€™s, @officialABAT, Renewed Hope Agenda to provide equitable and quality healthcare for all Nigerians as a matter of right and urgency.

On Tuesday, we inaugurated the Steering Committee for the Disability Inclusive Health Initiative, highlighting the barriers faced by people with disabilities when accessing healthcare in Nigeria. 

With about 15-20% of our population living with disabilities, we aim to ensure that our efforts to provide an efficient, equitable, and quality health system do not leave out any citizen of our country.

The Committee will provide actionable recommendations on how we can better support persons living with disabilities by enforcing anti-discrimination laws and ensuring the rights of people with disabilities, especially as they pertain to healthcare, are upheld. 

We value the insights from the SSA to the President on Disability, @AimohT, and other partners like the Missing Billions Initiative, @_missingbillion, and @McKforSociety. Their recommendation for a cross-ministerial approach to enhance healthcare access, provide assistive technologies, and implement rapid diagnostic services are crucial for supporting PWDs and other marginalized groups.

We also commend the ongoing efforts by @Fmohnigeria, @NphcdaNG, @NhisNg, the Federal Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs, Disaster Management and Social Development @fmha_pa, @NcpwdOfficial and other government agencies to improve access to quality care, health insurance, and social welfare services.

Our shared commitment to promoting effective policies and boosting investments in targeted programs will address physical infrastructure challenges, eliminate communication barriers, and break down stereotypes that hinder PWDsâ€™ access to quality healthcare and social welfare services.

text:
The Federal Ministry of Health & Social Welfare (@Fmohnigeria) is committed to its strategic objective of improving population health outcomes in Nigeria, with a special focus on enhancing access to high-quality oncology care. This is a crucial part of our comprehensive Health Sector Renewal Investment Program, which also targets reproductive, maternal, child, and adolescent health among others.

With the rising incidence of non-communicable diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, etc, causing significant physical and financial burdens on Nigerians, the FMOH launched the Oncology Initiative in 2021. This initiative seeks to strengthen cancer care through targeted medical investments, including the establishment of nuclear medicine centers, upgrade of existing facilities, and the deployment of modern medical infrastructure in select tertiary hospitals. 

Despite initial implementation delays, there has been a Renewed Hope for this initiative under the leadership of President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT. Early in his administration, Mr President tasked us with accelerating collaborations with relevant ministries and agencies for its successful realization.

A significant milestone was achieved this Friday with the signing of a Partnership Agreement with the Nigeria Sovereign Investment Authority (@nsia_nigeria). The agreement aims to provide project management and advisory services to ensure the seamless implementation of the Oncology Initiative. In support of this endeavor, President Tinubu has allocated N37.4 billion to the FMOH Oncology Initiative, demonstrating the governmentâ€™s commitment to rapid and effective implementation.

To ensure equitable access to oncology care across the nation, six teaching hospitals have been selected for the initiative, covering all geopolitical zones:

https://t.co/Nbmeh64ngI of Benin Teaching Hospital (@ubthng)
2.Ahmadu Bello University Teaching Hospital (@abuthshika)
3.Federal Teaching Hospital Katsina (@Official_fthk)
https://t.co/EiP2wFiHJ3 of Nigeria Teaching Hospital (@officialunth)
5.Jos University Teaching Hospital (JUTH)
6.Lagos University Teaching Hospital (@LUTHofficial)

These institutions will be equipped with advanced medical infrastructure, including linear accelerators, iridium brachytherapy machines, computed tomography (CT) simulators, positron emission tomography (PET) scanners, and cyclotrons. The goal is to ensure precise diagnosis and effective management of oncology cases, thereby alleviating the physical and financial strains faced by Nigerians.

The milestone weâ€™ve reached through the agreement is a testament to what is possible with the right governance and bold leadership, as exemplified by President Tinubu. And weâ€™re quite confident that with a people-oriented approach, no challenge is too great to overcome in our journey.

In the coming weeks, the agreement will be reviewed and endorsed by NSIAâ€™s Governing Board. We will collaborate with the Standards Organization of Nigeria (@SONNigeria) and the Nigerian Nuclear Regulatory Authority (@NNRA_Official) for effective monitoring and implementation. To ensure transparency, CSOs, media, and the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (@officialEFCC) will be critical in monitoring spending and preventing misappropriation of funds. Also, plans are in place to set up a central oversight committee comprising of specialists to oversee project implementation and fund flows, thereby ensuring proper use of resources.

Our target is to complete the construction of the six oncology centers with the appropriate equipment, staffing, training programs, and regulatory frameworks within the next 18-24 months.

We call upon the goodwill and collaboration of all Nigerians and agencies to ensure transparent operation and delivery of targeted value to our people. The interests of the Nigerian people must remain paramount as we strive to fulfill the goals of the Oncology Initiative for the betterment of our nation and in service to God and country.

text:
It was a great pleasure to participate today in the EU-AU Partnership on Global Health high-level event in Brussels, Belgium.

Organized by the @EU_Commission, the @_AfricanUnion (AU), and the @AfricaCDC, the event focused on strengthening the foundation of shared ambitions between the EU and AU in Global Health.

It was particularly reassuring to note that the priority areas for the EU-AU Global Health partnership resonate with our Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative, which aims to deliver improved population health outcomes for all Nigerians and promote health security, among others.

Particularly, the focus on strengthening health systems, pandemic preparedness and response (PPR), health security through a One Health approach, and fighting Anti-Microbial Resistance (#AMR), as well as accelerating the digital transformation of health, adds significant impetus to our framework for achieving Universal Health Coverage (#UHC) for all Nigerians.

I join other participants in commending the outcomes of the meeting. The call for the @_AfricanUnion and @EU_Commission to unify their voices at international policy levels and within Global Health Initiatives to support local regional manufacturing is key for public health and health security. It also aligns with our initiative to unlock the healthcare value chain. 

We wholeheartedly endorse the message from my brother, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (@DrTedros), emphasizing the importance of learning from the lessons of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is crucial to break the cycle of panic and neglect, as the threat of pandemics is ever-present, and it is not a question of if, but when the next pandemic will occur. In light of this, we urge all parties to make sincere efforts to achieve a fair Pandemic Accord and to revise the International Health Regulations to better prepare for future global health challenges.

We welcome the emphasis on Primary Health Care as the most inclusive, effective, and efficient approach to enhancing peopleâ€™s physical and mental health, including sexual and reproductive health, and social well-being through a well sustained Human Resources for Health.

As the AU Champion for Human Resources for Health and Community Health Delivery Partnership, His Excellency President Bola Ahmed Tinubu @officialABAT has authorized a unified approach to ensure that Nigeria, and indeed Africa, can boast of a well-trained, remunerated health workforce, including a recognized community health workforce.

I also appreciate Franceâ€™s Minister of Health Hon Dr. Chrysoula Zacharopoulou @CZacharopoulou for her willingness to explore important collaborations between Nigeria and France in the global health arena.

The objectives of the Presidential Initiative, @officialABAT, to unlock Nigeriaâ€™s healthcare value chain include the restructuring of the nationâ€™s health product manufacturing ecosystem to enhance domestic production of life-saving medicines, vaccines, and biologics.

In pursuit of this goal, we have engaged with a diverse range of companies, both domestically and internationally, to foster the development of new biotech capabilities in Nigeria, including the creation of high-quality jobs in the health and pharmaceutical sectors.

Over the past 12 weeks, we (@Fmohnigeria) have observed and documented significant interest from leading industry figures, including both private and publicly traded firms, in collaborating with Nigeria to drive the health sector renewal investment agenda and to positively transform the value chain.

Today, in Brussels, we are thrilled to announce the signing of a landmark Memorandum of Understanding with Univercells SA, a Belgian public limited liability company.

The MoU focuses on the adoption of biotechnology for Nigeria and aims to facilitate cooperation in establishing the necessary infrastructure, including training capabilities for local research, development, and manufacturing of medicines of both human and animal public health importance.

This agreement represents a major step forward in realizing our ambition to save more lives and provide affordable healthcare for all Nigerians. We extend our gratitude to the leadership of Univercells, particularly Hugues Bultot, CEO of @Univercells_sa and Group Co-Founder; JosÃ© Castillo, CEO of Quantoom Biosciences and Group Co-Founder; Hala Audi, CEO of Unizima and Chief Alliance Officer of Univercells; and other senior members of the Group, for their vote of confidence in our efforts.

text:
The full engagement of private sector entities in our mission to restructure the health products ecosystem, particularly in catalyzing domestic manufacturing of generic pharmaceuticals, vaccines, biologics, and devices, is the cornerstone of the Presidential â€˜Unlocking Healthcare Value-Chainâ€™ Initiative (PVAC). 

The PVAC Initiative is a clear demonstration of President Bola Ahmed Tinubuâ€™s @officialABAT, commitment to addressing the acute shortage of medicines and other health products that has long plagued Nigerians, causing undue financial and physical hardships.

In collaboration with other Ministries, Agencies, and partners, we are rapidly unlocking the value chain, and our approach is twofold. Firstly, we are engaging with Nigerian private sector players; and secondly, we are attracting foreign investors and partners. Our consistent message has been that â€œInvesting in the Nigerian pharmaceutical and medical sectors is smart business.â€ And we are witnessing promising results across the board.

The groundbreaking ceremony, today, for the Phase 2 of the Nigerian AMA Medical Manufacturing Plant in Kaduna State, which I had the honor of conducting alongside Dr. Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala @NOIweala, Director-General of the World Trade Organization @wto, was a clear lead. 

We were particularly impressed with the state-of-the-art production plant for high-quality intravenous solutions (IV fluids) at affordable costs, which utilizes European technology, including the Automatic Form Fill Seal (AFFS) Technology. Proudly, the facility is on par with what is available in advanced economies.

The successful establishment of the AMA Medical Manufacturing Plant and its world-class facilities reaffirm our belief in the power of innovation and resilience, as well as the boundless possibilities that lie ahead for our country. 

AMA Medicals has set a benchmark, demonstrating to potential investors that Nigeria is a viable and attractive destination for investment.

I extend my congratulations to Alhaji Musa Bello, Chairman of AMA Medical Manufacturing Plant, and the team of experts who have made this initiative a reality.

As part of our unwavering commitment to saving lives and improving health outcomes for all Nigerians, we are dedicated to providing an enabling regulatory framework (@NafdacAgency) and appropriate incentives to enhance economies of scale for both national and foreign businesses, in line with the Presidentâ€™s agenda. 

Nigeria, with a market of 240 million people, and as a gateway to the regional market, is open for business; and we welcome all serious investors.

text:

text:
Significant portion of our population, particularly at the rural community level, simply require basic services to make a huge difference in their lives and livelihoods. These services include access to food, clean water, shelter, vaccines, protection from malaria, treatment, and prenatal and antenatal care, among others.

Our goal to save lives, reduce financial and physical burdens, and provide health for all Nigerians is to be achieved by addressing these needs, using a sector-wide approach with primary healthcare as foundation.

We recognize that the federal government cannot, by itself alone, provide all the solutions to the country's healthcare and social welfare challenges. Indeed, the Sector-Wide Approach and Compact under the Health Sector Renewal Investment Initiative envisions a whole-of-society engagement model. This includes non-state actors such as leaders of Faith-Based Organizations (#FBOs), Traditional Institutions, and other Civil Society Organizations.

Our experience in eliminating the wild poliovirus from Nigeria is a testament to the moral authority, trust, credibility, and convening power of these leaders in their communities and among their followers. Therefore, we regard FBOs and Traditional Institutions as faithful partners in successfully implementing our agenda to improve health outcomes for our people.

Today's meetings with the leadership and members of the Catholic Bishops Conference of Nigeria, @CBCN_NG; and also separately with Her Regal Majesty, Amb. Dr. Olori Temitope Enitan Ogunwusi, @herregalmajesty, Southwest Malaria Advocate for the National Malaria Elimination Programme, have reinforced our confidence in this people-centered endeavor.

We understand the immense contributions of FBOs in providing equitable and non-discriminatory healthcare services, critical role in bridging the gap in accessing essential care and prevention. This is delivered within supportive traditional institutional setting, communities, where our Emirs, Obas, Obis, Oonies, Igwes, and other Royal leaders inspire and lead their people to embrace various primary healthcare campaigns and routine services.

We express our gratitude to Rev. Fr. Uchechukwu Obodoechina, PhD, for leading the visit and for faithfully representing the goodwill and support offered by the CBCN to the @Fmohnigeria. We deeply appreciate the sacrifices, commitments, and dedication of Caritas Nigeria @CCFNigeria, in promoting good population health outcomes in the country and reaching the last mile of caregiving. We also appreciate the efforts of Her Regal Majesty, Amb. Dr. Olori Ogunwusi, as a lead advocate in south west, towards the elimination of malaria. Your work is critical to solving an age-long challenge of malaria burden.

Mr. President, @officialABAT,  has approved the establishment of a Social Action Fund, which will be designed and launched soon, channeled to communities to empower them to live healthier and better lives.

We are looking forward to the first National Consultative Forum on health, human and social capital, soon, where we will engage with, listen to, our Royal Fathers and Mothers, FBOs and Non-Governmental entities,  on how we can better deploy available resources for health to the benefit of all Nigerians. We are grateful to know that you support Mr Presidentâ€™s direction.

#IWD2024. 

The Administration of H.E. President Bola Ahmed Tinubu, GCFR @officialABAT, is committed to improving the health and wellbeing of Nigerian women and the girl-child to empower them to prosper and thrive. 

This is in line with the theme of #IWD2024 to promote investments in women and accelerate progress against gender-based factors that disempower and exclude women from prosperity and healthy living. 

Therefore, the Nigeria Health Sector Renewal Investment Programme [#NHSRIP] is designed with a full gender lens and is already delivering the following: 

1. Increase access to essential healthcare services for women and girls through the prioritization of primary healthcare revitalization.

2. Over 550,000 attend their first Antenatal Care (ANC) appointments, ensuring they receive the necessary information and care to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce maternal and child mortality.

3. Enrollment of about 750,000 more Nigerians in health insurance, through the VGF at @NhisNg, providing them with financial protection.

4. Successful high coverage of #HPV vaccination for eligible girls aged 9-14 years, in 15 States, protecting them against cervical cancer.

5. Planned Targeted investments in infrastructure and capacity building in federal tertiary hospitals, enhancing healthcare services for women with complex health conditions, including the North East Vesico-Vaginal Fistula Hospital in Ningi.

6. Commitment to advancing healthcare data management and developing policies on cosmetics safety and food safety, safeguarding the health and well-being of women and girls.

7. Support for medical industrialization initiatives, unlocking opportunities for women's empowerment and economic participation in the healthcare sector.

8. Today, we add our strong voice and take a stand against economic disempowerment, social exclusion, female genital mutilation, gender-based violence and all forms of abuse or discrimination against women and girls. 

And we are not stopping there. The whole programme we are implementing, under the NHSRIP, for improving population health outcomes has Nigerian women and girls at front and center of our interventions.

Happy International Womenâ€™s Day. #IWD2024

It is not acceptable that more than 70 years since Nigeria began implementing programs to eliminate malaria,we still bear 30% of the global burden, with an estimated annual 68 million cases and 194, 000 deaths from the disease as of 2021. 

We need to reimagine the routine approaches that have so far defined our interventions over time. We must utilize newer evidence-based tools, quality data systems, strengthen our collaborations and partnerships,  develop smarter financing models and new procurement modalities to suit our realities in Nigeria as well the African continent. 

The Sector-Wide approach we have adopted to improve governance, converge resources, align efforts, and amplify impact of health outcomes will lead to success in this regard.

Our meeting with teams from the Malaria Alliance, RBM Malaria Partnership, and @WHO Global Malaria Program partners was to reassess our efforts and mobilize technical and financial resources towards eliminating the scourge of malaria. 

We are jointly considering initiatives, including development of domestic manufacturing of insecticide treated bed nets (ITNs), generic pharmaceuticals, introduction of appropriate, safe and cost effective vaccines, and potentially mosquito-repellent products, anchored on the Presidential Initiative to Unlock Health Sector Value Chain, to eradicate malaria from the country. 

This also requires strengthening our primary healthcare system for malaria testing and early treatment, especially for children,  antenatal mothers, and others. 

Mr President @officialABAT, as the â€œAfrican Union @_AfricanUnion Champion for Human Resources for Health and Community Health Deliveryâ€, is strongly supporting us to retrain 120,000 frontline health workers; and to double the number of functional primary health centers in the country from 8,800 to over 17,000 over the next three years, as part of the Health Sector Renewal Investment Program and accompanying sector-wide Compact.

After concluding the 37th Stop TB Board Meeting in Brasilia, we visited Rio de Janeiro to meet with scientists and management of Fio Cruz/Bio-Manguinhos @BioFiocruz, to understand how Brazil has achieved impressive public health standards modeling innovation, technological development, production of immunobiologicals, and providing services to meet the countryâ€™s needs.

It was good to hear how the Brazilian federal government, over time shaped its healthcare value chain by securing technological transfers with major global companies, enabling local manufacturing of essential public health commodities, with market guarantee by the federal government. This helped in unlocking huge potentials and securing essential diagnostics, vaccines and pharmaceuticals for Brazilâ€™s needs in crisis situations. Similar to Nigeria, Brazil has a large population.

We were also interested to understand the partnership model underpinning the long-standing collaboration between Bio-Manguinhos / Fiocruz and the Chembio Diagnostics Inc / Biosynex Group @ChembioDx, which specializes in the design and distribution of rapid tests for point-of-care diagnostics at scale.

In November 2023, the Chembio Diagnostics Inc / Biosynex Group  France expressed intent to establish a local manufacturing outfit in Nigeria, enabling transfer of knowledge how, building Nigerian talent, creating economic value and safeguarding our health security in crisis times.

We were also glad with the outcome of our discussion with FPG Brands, a SÃ£o Paulo Brazil-based  investment holding company, committing to invest US $240 million in Nigeriaâ€™s health value chain within the next 2 years.  This contrasts with the narrative that some may wish on us, that investors are leaving. Serious investors who see the ultimate promise of Nigeriaâ€™s renewal/renaissance  are betting on our optimistic future, in the long run. Thank you FPG for the confidence to come in.
